docs.lead_paragraph: At 88, Nathan, a New York businessman with a sharp, clear mind, was still going to work every day. Then an episode that resembled a ministroke landed him in the hospital, where numerous medications were administered. Within days, Nathan's mind and memory had turned to mush. The family was ready to put him in a nursing home when, at a knowledgeable relative's request, the drug regimen was reviewed and several drugs of questionable necessity were discontinued. Nathan soon returned to his previous mental state and was able to continue working for several more years.

headline.main: As Prescriptions Pile Up, Risks Do, Too

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on polypharmacy, interaction of three, four or more drugs that together have very adverse side effects; notes problem is increasingly common now that so many people live to age at which nagging physical discomforts and chronic health problems often arise; cites steps to reduce problem; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In recent months, researchers have pointed to possible signals of Alzheimer's disease that could allow doctors to detect the ailment before symptoms start. They have spoken of small areas of the brain that appear to shrink, and psychological tests that yield subtle clues. Now scientists think they may have found another clue: smell.

headline.main: Hints of Alzheimer's Found in the Nose

docs.abstract: Researchers say problems identifying aromas may indicate early Alzheimer's disease, but only when patients do not realize that something is amiss with sense of smell (S)
docs.snippet: In recent months, researchers have pointed to possible signals of Alzheimer's disease that could allow doctors to detect the ailment before symptoms start. They have spoken of small areas of the brain that appear to shrink, and psychological tests...

docs.lead_paragraph: For all the corporate enthusiasm over the unveiling of each new generation of computer chip (last month Intel announced that its Pentium 4 would be packed with 42 million transistors performing as many as 8.4 billion operations per second), consumers may be more apt to feel a sense of dread. Once again the expensive desktop computers and laptops they were so proud of have become outmoded, destined to join the scrap piles of unsalable equipment accumulating in closets everywhere. Moore's law, which holds that computing power doubles approximately every 18 months, sometimes seems less a blessing than a curse. But the law cannot hold forever, and Dr. Seth Lloyd, an associate professor of mechanical engineering at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, offers hope that the end is in sight.
docs.abstract: Dr Seth Lloyd, in article in journal Nature, describes ultimate laptop commuter, plumbing limits nature sets on computation; effort, part of relatively new discipline called physics of information, gives computer engineers ideal to aim for and may help deepen understanding between physics and information and explore idea that natural processes can be thought of as computations; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People who want to start exercise programs but feel they don't have enough time or energy to begin should think again. A new study suggests that physical activity that lasts just 15 minutes, if done often enough, may be as beneficial as longer workouts. The report appeared last week in Circulation: Journal of the American Heart Association.
docs.abstract: Study finds that exercise that lasts just 15 minutes, if done often enough, may be as beneficial in reducing heart-disease risk as longer workouts; finds that total amount of time spent exercising, not length of each session, seems to be most important; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: People who want to start exercise programs but feel they don't have enough time or energy to begin should think again.    A new study suggests that physical activity that lasts just 15 minutes, if done often enough, may be as beneficial as longer...

docs.lead_paragraph: For many menopausal women, the question of whether to take hormones is one of the most crucial health decisions of their middle years -- and one of the most confusing. Yes, the hormones relieve the hot flashes and the night sweats that plague many women during menopause, and they protect against brittle bones.

headline.main: Hormone Replacement Therapy: Why They Do It, or Avoid It

docs.abstract: Menopausal women weigh a number of factors in deciding whether or not to undergo estrogen replacement therapy; six women tell how they made their decisions; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Modern doctors may be able to look to the paintings of Old Masters like Raphael and Rembrandt for practice in assessing their patients' general health and finding clues about their ailments. By studying the health of the models used by artists, Dr. Carlos H. Espinel, a Colombian-born general practitioner and art enthusiast, has devised a discipline that he calls ArtMedicine. By examining paintings, Dr. Espinel said he can diagnose conditions suffered by subjects in portraits made centuries ago.

headline.main: In Old Paintings, Hints of Subjects' Medical Ailments

docs.abstract: Carlos H Espinel, medical doctor and art enthusiast, says modern doctors can diagnose conditions suffered by subjects in portraits painted centuries ago; teaches discipline he calls ArtMedicine (M)
docs.snippet: Modern doctors may be able to look to the paintings of Old Masters like Raphael and Rembrandt for practice in assessing  their patients' general health and finding clues about their ailments.    By studying the health of the models used by artists,...

docs.lead_paragraph: Feeling sick to one's stomach may have more to do with the brain than the stomach. Researchers at Ohio State University say in a new study that they may have uncovered the reason that, often, people feel nauseated, even though what ails them has nothing to do with their digestive tracts. The culprit may be a brain chemical called tumor necrosis factor, or T.N.F., which the immune system releases at the first sign that the body is coming under attack. The factor acts on a part of the brain stem that regulates the digestive tract, including vomiting, said the study published in The American Journal of Physiology: Gastrointestinal and Liver Physiology.

headline.main: Sick in the Head, and in the Stomach

docs.abstract: Ohio State University researchers say nausea reported by people with ailments unrelated to digestive tract may be traced to tumor necrosis factor, brain chemical the immune system releases at first sign body is coming under attack; factor acts on part of brain stem that regulates digestive tract, including vomiting; drawing (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With the rate of Caesarean sections on the rise, a leading group of obstetricians has issued guidelines that may reduce the number of operations. This month, the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced that, for the third year in a row, surgically assisted deliveries were up, after a period of decline that began in 1989.
docs.abstract: American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists, responding to renewed increase in Caesarean sections, suggests steps hospitals can take to cut number of such operations and spur vaginal deliveries (S)

keywords.value: AMERICAN COLLEGE OF OBSTETRICIANS AND GYNECOLOGISTS

docs.lead_paragraph: Last year, when I was an intern, I took care of a man in his 70's with a peculiar problem: When he was sleeping, he would periodically stop breathing. When he was awake, he was lethargic and disoriented, sometimes psychotic. No one on my team knew what was wrong with him. I still don't. One day the supervising physician, a smart and able man, was on the ward perusing the patient's voluminous chart. ''You know what?'' he said to me. ''One day they're going to talk about this guy like they talked about AIDS patients 20 years ago. He falls outside our paradigm. He's a real mystery.''

headline.main: Teaching Hospitals Too Busy for Curiosity

docs.abstract: Dr Sandeep Jauhar column notes doctors in teaching hospitals lack time to devote to patients with unusual ailments; holds such hospitals, which once stoked intellectual curiosity, are succumbing to pressures of cost-cutting and 10-minute patient visits that affect rest of medicine; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Real men don't get colds. Or they should be less susceptible to them, anyway, because a new study finds that tough guys seem to have tougher immune systems, the body's natural defense for fighting off infections, viruses and the like.
docs.abstract: Researchers find that moderately aggressive men have higher levels of two types of lymphocytes that help control immune response; find highly aggressive men do not share in benefit; Dr Douglas A Granger, co-author of report, notes women, in general, seem to have stronger immune systems than men; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Real men don't get colds.    Or they should be less susceptible to them, anyway, because a new study finds that tough guys seem to have tougher immune systems, the body's natural defense for fighting off infections, viruses and the like.
